Award.AwardTitle: Feedback of cell cycle on cell type in Arabidopsis organogenesis
Award.AbstractNarration: The world will need to increase agricultural yields dramatically to meet the demands of the rapidly growing population for food and renewable fuel. The edible parts of several major food plants, including corn, rice, wheat, beans, and peas, undergo a specialized process called endoreduplication in which their cells enlarge and increase their DNA content several fold. Despite its importance, little is known about how endoreduplication is regulated, and it is difficult to investigate in food plants because the endoreduplicating nutritive tissues are buried deep within their developing seeds. To overcome this difficulty, the research proposed will use genetics, cell biology, and genomics to investigate endoreduplication in exposed cells on the surface of the Arabidopsis flower. In this new system, the cells are accessible for experimentation in growing plants. In particular, the research will address the question of how endoreduplication influences the cell undergoing the process. First, a mutant with increased numbers of endoreduplicated cells will be used to elucidate how endoreduplication is controlled. Second, the mechanism through which endoreduplication turns off one gene will be determined. Normally scientists think of external signals turning on and off genes within a cell. However, exciting recent results suggests that in, at least one case, endoreduplication can turn off a gene. Finally, to find how many genes are turned on or off by endoreduplication, the expression levels of all of the genes in the Arabidopsis genome will be compared between endoreduplicating cells and their non-endoreduplicating neighbors. Findings from this research may show new ways to increase crop yield. In addition, this project will train two graduate students, provide opportunities for summer research for three undergraduate students, and will enable workshops targeted to interest school girls in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the key questions in biology is what makes cells large or small. Generally, a cell grows to about twice its original size, copies its DNA, and divides to make two cells. Each new cell has the same DNA and is the same size as the original cell. Thus, cells usually keep the same size. However, some specialized cells in both plants and animals behave differently. They carry out a process called endoreduplication, in which the cell grows and copies its DNA, but never divides into two cells; instead, the cell keeps on growing. These cells typically become highly enlarged and contain many copies of the DNA. Endoreduplication happens in the edible parts of several major food crops, including the corn kernel, the rice grain, wheat kernel, beans, and peas. Not all cells in these edible parts endoreduplicate, and the cells that do endoreduplicate may not do it very much. Increasing endoreduplication could make these crops yield more food and be more nutritious. But to make that happen, we need to learn how to control endoreduplication. Studying the endoreduplicating cells of food crops is difficult because they are deep inside seeds and not easy to see. Therefore, we studied endoreduplication in a highly visible plant organ, the outermost cells of the flower in the small model plant Arabidopsis thaliana (thale cress). This let us ask two scientific questions. How does a plant cell decide to endoreduplicate? And what are the consequences of endoreduplication on the cell?

Through our research, we discovered two ways that plants regulate endoreduplication of their cells. Previous scientists had studied how endoreduplication was affected by proteins that directly control the dividing cell cycle. To go beyond this, we looked for regulators that act before these cell-cycle proteins. We found that the SEC24A protein, which controls how other proteins are moved through the cell, surprisingly also inhibits endoreduplication. We then found that increasing the concentration of a master regulatory protein (ATML1, which turns on and off other genes) increased endoreduplication. Furthermore, we found that both ATML1 and SEC24 affect endoreduplication through regulating an inhibitor of cell division. Thus, we found two genetic changes (increased ATML1 or decreased SEC24) in plants that increase both the number of cells that endoreduplicate and the amount of DNA inside these cells.

We studied how endoreduplication controls cell growth: does endoreduplication increase how quickly cells grow, or does it merely force them to be large by keeping them from dividing? We found the latter answer is correct. Endoreduplication does not speed up cell growth, but it does produce larger cells in the end by blocking cell division and giving the cell more time to grow.

Finally, we found that endoreduplication controls the expression of hundreds of genes in Arabidopsis plant cells. Surprisingly, many of these genes are involved in the defensive responses of plants to being infected by bacteria or fungi or eaten by insects. This showed that endoreduplication can not only make cells large but also help them gain new functions that are beneficial to the plant.

An important goal of this project was to train young, new scientists. Three graduate students have been trained in advanced plant molecular genetics techniques, genomics, confocal live imaging and computational image processing through doing research in this project. Two of them have earned PhD degrees and are continuing their work as postdoctoral researchers in Washington and California. The third graduate student is completing her work in the laboratory and is expected to also earn her PhD at Cornell. As part of the Boyce Thompson Institute (BTI) Cornell Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program, three undergraduate interns from outside New York came to our Cornell laboratory for the summer. Each intern wrote a short research proposal, carried out experiments over 10 weeks, and presented the results in symposium talks. Four other undergraduates from Cornell also carried out research on this project, working in the laboratory over the summer, some for several years. Two of these Cornell students completed honors theses. These undergraduates were recognized with coauthorships or acknowledgements in research papers; after graduating, they are pursuing advanced scientific and medical degrees or further scientific research. Finally, through the Explore Your Opportunities (EYO) Conference organized by the American Association of University Women, the graduate students and I have led hands-on workshops for seventh-grade girls at Mount Saint Vincent College in the Bronx, New York. In these workshops, the girls competed to see who could separate the most different plant pigments from flowers, fruits, and vegetables using paper chromatography. The girls also interacted directly with us as scientists, learned about our career paths through college and beyond, and recognized the diversity of scientific careers, hearing about some of them for the first time.
